dmca.title: Prisoner Advocacy Site Claims that Prison Penpal Service Is Lifting Text
dmca.body:
[private]
The Other Side of the Wall
[private]
Fairfax, CA 94930

xxx-xxx-xxxx
[private]@[private]

August 26, 2003

Google, Inc.
Attn: Customer Support, DMCA Complaints
[private]
Mountain View, CA 94043

Dear Google:

	This letter is to inform you about the following site, which 
appears on Google, that has wrongfully taken the entire material 
from my web page and used it as its own in violation of copyright law 
and DMCA standards.

1.	The original material is from The Prisoner's Dictionary: 
	<http://dictionary.prisonwall.org>

2.	The copyrighted material that is being used appears on

	<http:www.boyzbehindbars.com/connections/dictionary.html>

3.	The search queries that I used to find the infringing web page on Google were:

	a. boyzbehindbars

	b. boyzbehindbars.com

	c. prison dictionary

	d. prison slang

	e. prisoner dictionary

	In some cases, searching within the results was easier, 
although <www.boyzbehindbars.com/connections/dictionary.html> was 
the fourth result given in the "prison dictionary" search.

	4.	My contact information is listed above. The infringing page is owned by [private], BoyzBehindBars.com, [private], Atlanta, GA 30321-xxxx. [private]'s email address is: [private]@[private].

	5.	I have a good faith belief that use of the copyrighted materials described above on the allegedly infringing web pages is not authorized by the copyright owner, its agent, or the law.

	In particular, the cached version of the infringing page that is displayed on Google (as of today) still contains the links to the Amazon associates account for the Other Side of the Wall: (http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/0916500144/theothersideofth). 
BoyzBehindBars changed these links after they were notified that this 
demonstrated their blatant copyright infringement, but I have 
retained a .pdf copy of the page should the Google cached version be 
changed.

	The Internet Archive at http://web.archive.org/web contains version of my dictionary at dictionary.prisonwall.org from the year 2000 (when the subdomain was established), including the 2001-2002 page that BoyzBehindBars copied (and wrongfully ascribed its own copyright).

	The Internet Archive at http://web.archive.org/web contains copies of my dictionary that was found at its former address at www.wco.com/~aerick/lingo.htm going back as far as December, 1996.

	The Internet Archive at http://web.archive.org/web contained the BoyzBehindBars dictionary from February, 2002. It also contains the links to my Amazon associate account.

	The Prisoner's Dictionary was established in 1995 and has been featured on various internet sites as well as academic and news publications. I have established a separate page to call attention to the copyright infringement (which is also found on the Google search engine) at http://prisons.home.comcast.net.

	I notified [private] and requested him to remove the dictionary from his web page, including the copyright notice that he attached to my material. He responded, "Get over yourself The page stays where its at." I notified his parent company, [private]Intemet Services of this and [private] responded by changing the links to my Amazon associate account, but left the infringing material in its place.

	[private] has been notified that this site infringes upon copyright law and the protections afforded the DCMA [sic].

	6.	I swear, under penalty of perjury, that the information in the notification is accurate and that I am the copyright owner or am authorized to act on behalf of the owner of an exclusive right that is allegedly infringed,

Signed this 26th day of September at Fairfax, California.

[private]
dmca.principal_name: The other side of the wall
